revision.text:
{{for|the American shopping mall|Randall Park Mall}} {{Infobox person |name = Randall Park |image = Randall Park in NY on February 4, 2015 Photo by Lia Chang.jpg |caption = Park in New York, 2015 |birth_date = March 23, 1974 (age 44) |birth_place = [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], U.S. |occupation = Actor, comedian, writer |yearsactive = 2003â€“present |alma_mater = [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (B.A., M.A.) |residence = [[San Fernando Valley]], [[California]], U.S.{{cite news|author=[[Ashok Kondabolu]]|title=Ashok and Randall Park Celebrate Father's Day|newspaper=[[Asian American Writers' Workshop]]|date=July 26, 2013|url=http://aaww.org/ashok-and-randall-park|accessdate=December 17, 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.laweekly.com/publicspectacle/2014/02/13/randall-and-jae-suh-park-baby-makes-three|title=Randall and Jae Suh Park: Baby Makes Three|work=[[LA Weekly]]|date=February 13, 2014|first=Ada|last=Tseng|accessdate=December 25, 2014}} |spouse = {{Marriage|[[Jae Suh Park]]|2008}} |children = 1 |website = {{URL|www.randallparkplace.com}} }} '''Randall Park''' (born March 23, 1974){{cite web|url=http://www.intelius.com/results.php?ReportType=1&formname=name&qf=Randall+&qmi=&qn=Park&qcs=Los+Angeles%2C+CA&focusfirst=1|title=People Search & Directory Services|publisher=Intelius.com|accessdate=17 January 2013}} is an American actor, comedian and writer known for portraying North Korean supreme leader [[Kim Jong-un]] in the 2014 film ''[[The Interview]]'', Minnesota governor Danny Chung in ''[[Veep (TV series)|Veep]]'', [[Eddie Huang]]'s father, American restaurateur Louis Huang, in [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s television show ''[[Fresh Off the Boat]]'' and most recently, FBI agent [[Jimmy Woo]] in the 2018 film ''[[Ant-Man and the Wasp]]''. ==Early life== Park was born to [[Korea]]n immigrant parents in [[Los Angeles]], [[California]]. He was raised in [[West Los Angeles]]. His mother was an accountant at [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]], and his father owned a [[Versamat|one-hour photo store]].{{cite web|url=http://iamkoream.com/off-script-with-randall-park|title=Off Script with Randall Park|publisher=KoreAm|date=December 23, 2014|first=Ada|last=Tseng|accessdate=December 25, 2014}} Park graduated from [[Hamilton High School (Los Angeles)|Hamilton High School]]'s Humanities Magnet Program.{{cite web|url=http://iamkoream.com/april-issue-randall-park-reflects-on-the-riots|title=April Issue: Randall Park Reflects on the Riots|publisher=Iamkoream.com/Korean Journal|accessdate=17 January 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ovguide.com/randall-park-9202a8c04000641f8000000000e7e095|title=Randall Park Video | Celebrity Interview and Paparazzi|publisher=Ovguide.com|accessdate=17 January 2013}} Park earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in English and creative writing and a [[master's degree]] in [[Asian American studies]] from UCLA.{{cite web|author=Edward|url=http://www.8asians.com/2011/01/04/the-working-apa-actor-randall-park|title=The Working APA Actor: Randall Park|publisher=8Asians.com|date=January 4, 2011|accessdate=17 January 2013}} While attending UCLA, Park co-founded the largest and longest running University Asian American theater company named "Lapu, the Coyote that Cares", which is now known as the LCC Theatre Company.{{citeweb|title=About: History|url=http://www.lcctheatre.com/about.php|publisher=LCC Theatre Company at UCLA}}{{citeweb|title=Cast: Alumni and Inactive Cast|url=http://www.lcctheatre.com/cast.php|publisher=LCC Theatre Company at UCLA}}{{citenews|title=Meet Propergander (Part I)|url=http://www.international.ucla.edu/ccs/article/28398|publisher=[[UCLA]] International Institute|date=August 16, 2005}} ==Career== ===Film and television=== Park made his acting debut in the 2003 short film ''Dragon of Love'' (as the main character, Joel), which won the Best Short Film at the 2003 [[Hawaii International Film Festival]]. He has appeared in feature films such as ''[[Larry Crowne]]'', ''[[Dinner for Schmucks]]'', and ''[[The Five-Year Engagement]]''. He appeared in various independent film projects such as [[Quentin Lee]]'s ''[[The People I've Slept With]]'' (2009) and starred and co-wrote the feature film ''American Fusion'' (2005).[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0448989/ IMDB, ''American Fusion'' (2005)] Park has made guest appearances on television shows including ''[[Community (TV Series)|Community]],'' ''[[Curb Your Enthusiasm]],'' ''[[New Girl (TV series)|New Girl]],'' ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)|The Office]],'' ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', ''[[CSI: Crime Scene Investigation]]'', ''[[Four Kings]]'', ''[[Las Vegas (TV series)|Las Vegas]]'', ''[[House (TV series)|House]]'', ''[[iCarly]],'' ''[[Cold Case]]'', ''[[The Mindy Project]]'', and ''[[Reno 911!]]''. He appeared as Martin Fukanaga on ''[[Supah Ninjas]]'' and was a cast member on [[MTV]]'s ''[[Wild 'n Out]]''. In 2007, he regularly appeared as an actor in the filmmaking reality show ''[[On the Lot]]''. In 2014, Park played a company rep trying to recruit college students in ''[[Neighbors (2014 film)|Neighbors]]'', co-starred in the [[Jason Segel]]/[[Cameron Diaz]] comedy, ''[[Sex Tape (film)|Sex Tape]]'', which led to his being cast in ''[[The Interview]]'' (2014),{{cite news|title=Randall Park on ABC's New 'Fresh Off the Boat': The first Asian-American sitcom in 20 years premieres|last=Steinberg|first=Don|work=Wall Street Journal|date=February 4, 2015|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/1651187081/}} portraying [[Kim Jong-un]]. Park played the recurring character of Minnesota governor, Danny Chung on the [[HBO]] comedy ''[[Veep (TV series)|Veep]]''. He appeared as Jeff in the prequel 2015 series for [[Netflix]], ''[[Wet Hot American Summer: First Day of Camp]]''. In 2015 he also appeared in [[Wong Fu Productions]]' first feature film, ''[[Everything Before Us]]''. Since February 2015, Park has starred as Louis Huang, patriarch of a [[Chinese Americans|Chinese American]] family, alongside [[Constance Wu]], in [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s television show ''[[Fresh Off the Boat (TV series)|Fresh Off The Boat]]'' (based on [[Eddie Huang]]'s memoir, ''[[Fresh Off the Boat: A Memoir]]''), written and produced by [[Nahnatchka Khan]] and executive produced by Jake Kasdan.Nellie Andreeva. [http://www.deadline.com/2014/02/constance-wu-cast-in-fresh-off-the-boat-windell-middlebrooks-in-mason-twins "Constance Wu, Randall Park Join 'Fresh Off The Boat'; Windell Middlebrooks In 'Mason Twins'"], Deadline.com, February 7, 2014. He was the first actor cast on the show, with the producers having approached him before the pilot was ordered.{{Cite web|title=Sound and Fury Podcast Episode 18: Randall Park|url=http://blog.angryasianman.com/2015/01/sound-and-fury-podcast-episode-18.html|website=blog.angryasianman.com|accessdate=7 December 2015}} In 2015, Park appeared with [[John Malkovich]] in the music video for [[Eminem]]'s single "[[Phenomenal (song)|Phenomenal]]". He also appeared as a co-worker of [[Amy Schumer]]'s character in 2015's ''[[Trainwreck (film)|Trainwreck]].'' In 2015, Park also had roles in the films ''[[Southpaw]]'' (as Jed Wang) and ''[[The Night Before (2015 film)|The Night Before]]'' as Ethan's Boss. In 2016, Park appeared in the film ''[[Office Christmas Party]]'' as Fred and in 2017 appeared in the comedies ''[[The House (2017 film)|The House]]'' as the Wall Street Guy and ''[[The Disaster Artist]]''. He also lent his voice talents to the CGI animated film ''[[The Lego Ninjago Movie]]'' as Chen the Cheerleader. In 2018, Park played the role of FBI Agent [[Jimmy Woo]] in the [[Marvel Studios]] film ''[[Ant-Man and the Wasp]]''. He will also appear in the [[DC Extended Universe]] film ''[[Aquaman (film)|Aquaman]]'' as Dr. [[Stephen Shin]] in December, 2018. Park will star with [[Ali Wong]] in ''[[Always Be My Maybe (2019 film)|Always Be My Maybe]]'', a film directed by [[Nahnatchka Khan]], and written by Park, Wong and [[Michael Golamco]]. The film is slated for 2019. ===Writing and directing=== In 2005 Park co-wrote and starred in the feature film ''American Fusion'' directed by Frank Lin, which won the Audience Award at the [[Hawaii International Film Festival]]. He has also created, directed, written, and starred in several short [[Web series|internet series]] for [[Channel 101]], including ''Dr. Miracles'', ''The Food'', and ''Dumb Professor''. In 2013 he wrote and starred in a series for Channel 101 featuring his baby daughter entitled ''Baby Mentalist''.[http://blog.angryasianman.com/2013/04/the-further-adventures-of-baby-mentalist.html Angry Asian Man, Baby Mentalist], blog.angryasianman.com, April 2013. In Channel 101's bracket competition format for webseries, ''Baby Mentalist'' was voted number one the most times of any show at the time, ending with six episodes in 2013.{{Cite web|title=Channel 101 - Baby Mentalist|url=http://www.channel101.com/show/647|website=Channel 101|accessdate=7 December 2015}} Park wrote a short film, ''Blueberry'', which won an award for Best Actor at the [[NBC]] Shortcuts Film Festival For Short Films.{{cite web|url=http://www.gutsglamgrace.com/thescoop/entertainment/nbc-shortcuts|title=NBC Shortcuts|publisher=Guts.Glam.Grace|accessdate=17 January 2013}} He was awarded the [[Coalition of Asian Pacifics in Entertainment]] (CAPE) New Writers Award for his [[television pilot]] script, ''The Erasists.''{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcshortcuts.com/archives.html|title=Short Cuts Film Festival |publisher=Nbcshortcuts.com|date=6 August 2012|accessdate=17 January 2013}} Park also co-wrote a feature film with [[Ali Wong]] and [[Michael Golamco]] entitled ''[[Always Be My Maybe (2019 film)|Always Be My Maybe]]'', which is directed by [[Nahnatchka Khan]] and will be released in 2019. ===Commercials and online work=== Park has been featured in ads for [[HBO Go]], [[Ally Financial]], and the 2011 Father's Day [[Verizon Droid]] commercial.{{cite web | author=John | url=http://www.8asians.com/2011/05/23/asian-american-commercial-watch-randall-park-in-hbo-go | title=Asian American Commercial Watch: Randall Park in HBO Go | publisher=8Asians.com | date=23 May 2011|accessdate=17 January 2013}}{{cite web | url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A6LYLJbDQxc | title=Too Fast | publisher=[[YouTube]] | date=10 December 2010 | accessdate=17 January 2013}} He plays a "doggie daycare owner" in a print and online campaign for Chase Bank, which aired in early 2015.{{cite news | last1=Primack | first1=Dan | title=When 'Kim-Jong Un' did an ad for Chase Bank | url=http://fortune.com/2015/01/07/when-kim-jong-un-did-an-ad-for-chase-bank | accessdate=February 22, 2015|publisher=Fortune Magazine | date=January 7, 2015}} Park was featured in [[Wong Fu Productions]]' short film, ''Too Fast'' as Brandon, the web series ''Home Is Where the Hans Are'' as the stepfather and as Randall in their first feature film, ''[[Everything Before Us]]'' (2015).{{cite web | url=http://wongfuproductions.com/WFvideos/2010/12/too-fast-wong-fu-productions | title=Too Fast | website=Wong Fu Productions | date=December 2010}} Park was featured in UTC Business Ethics Course HUR750 "Respect in the Workplace". ==Personal life== Park is married to [[Jae Suh Park]] and they have one daughter. They live in the [[San Fernando Valley]]. ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year !! Title !!
